Working great now Gordon.  I was confused about how the decide rules
worked=
, thinking a reject from any rule would negate that URL.  I only
realized m=
y thinking was off when I read the javadocs for
DecideRuleSequence.  Lookin=
g back at the user manual, this is actually
described clearly in the line:
=

"Each rule is applied in turn to the candidate URI. If the rule
decides AC=
CEPT or REJECT, the URI's status is set accordingly."

An extra sentence in=
 there to make this crystal clear would be a big
help I think, though.  Som=
ething like: "As such, the last rule applied
in the sequence determines the=
 final status of the URI.  Order matters!"

Granted I might be in the lower=
 percentile segment of users, but that
definitely would have helped me had =
I caught a sentence like that!

Thanks very much.

-Adam


> 
> It could be=
 transcluded (if it were referred to by certain short chains
> of hops from=
 other URLs already in-scope), but removing the
> acceptIfTranscluded rule =
would eliminate that possibility.
> 
> If 'http://grx.com' appears in the c=
rawl.log, you can deduce the
> immediate predecessor URL, and hop-types tha=
t reached it, by the
> respective fields right after the URL in that log.
>=
 
> If it doesn't appear in the crawl.log, are you perhaps reading it
> out=
 of the discovered links of another URL, rather than seeing
> it be crawled=
 itself?
> 
> - Gordon @ IA
>
